guide.introduction: Here's a simple trick I discovered for etching designs on glass bottles using the bottle's label as a built-in resist.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Here's a simple trick I discovered for etching designs on glass bottles using the bottle's label as a built-in resist.

Relevant parts
  • Glass bottle
  • Etching cream
  • Paper towels
  • Rubbing Alcohol
Tools
  • Gloves
  • Hobby knife
  • Paintbrush
  • Permanent marker
  • Safety goggles
  • Sink
  • Tweezers

lines.text: I've been holding onto this bottle of 2006 Coppola Encyclopedia Tempranillo for a couple of years. The wine itself was really only suitable for cooking, but I love the bottle because it has a representation of the resveratrol molecule molded into the side.
lines.text_raw: I've been holding onto this bottle of 2006 Coppola Encyclopedia Tempranillo for a couple of years.  The wine itself was really only suitable for cooking, but I love the bottle because it has a representation of the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resveratrol|resveratrol] molecule molded into the side.

lines.text: This process probably requires a bottle with an adhesive plastic label. A sure sign that the label is suitable is is that parts of it are transparent.
lines.text_raw: This process probably requires a bottle with an adhesive plastic label. A sure sign that the label is suitable is is that parts of it are transparent.

lines.text: If you're going to cut your bottle, do so before attempting to etch a design on it, as the cutting process is considerably more failure-prone than etching.
lines.text_raw: If you're going to [guide|106|cut your bottle], do so before attempting to etch a design on it, as the cutting process is considerably more failure-prone than etching.

lines.text: Use a permanent marker or whatever you can find that will stick to the label.
lines.text_raw: Use a permanent marker or whatever you can find that will stick to the label.

lines.text: Try to choose a design that complements your bottle.  I chose a ball-and-stick model of the ethanol molecule to complement the resveratrol molecule molded into this bottle.
lines.text_raw: Try to choose a design that complements your bottle.  I chose a ball-and-stick model of the ethanol molecule to complement the resveratrol molecule molded into this bottle.

steps.title: Cut out positive areas of design

lines.text: Using your hobby knife or razor, carefully cut around the edges of your design.
lines.text_raw: Using your hobby knife or razor, carefully cut around the edges of your design.

lines.text: Lift the edges of the cut-out areas using the blade of your knife or razor.
lines.text_raw: Lift the edges of the cut-out areas using the blade of your knife or razor.

lines.text: Finish peeling off each positive cut using a pair of tweezers.
lines.text_raw: Finish peeling off each positive cut using a pair of tweezers.

lines.text: Wipe down the cut stencil with a paper towel generously soaked with rubbing alcohol.  This will remove any residual ink and, most importantly, clean any remaining adhesive from the cut-out areas.
lines.text_raw: Wipe down the cut stencil with a paper towel generously soaked with rubbing alcohol.  This will remove any residual ink and, most importantly, clean any remaining adhesive from the cut-out areas.

lines.text: To make sure the remaining stencil is firmly adhered to the bottle everywhere, wrap a scrap of paper around the bottle, over the label, and rub it briskly with the side of your marker.
lines.text_raw: To make sure the remaining stencil is firmly adhered to the bottle everywhere, wrap a scrap of paper around the bottle, over the label, and rub it briskly with the side of your marker.

lines.text: Generously daub etching cream over the exposed positive areas of your design using a brush.
lines.text_raw: Generously daub etching cream over the exposed positive areas of your design using a brush.

lines.text: Leave the etching cream in place 5 minutes, or whatever the label says, and then wash away all traces of the cream with plenty of warm water in the sink.
lines.text_raw: Leave the etching cream in place 5 minutes, or whatever the label says, and then wash away all traces of the cream with plenty of warm water in the sink.

lines.text: Glass etchants are toxic and should be handled with care.  Wear gloves and goggles and follow the label directions closely.
lines.text_raw: Glass etchants are toxic and should be handled with care.  Wear gloves and goggles and follow the label directions closely.

lines.text: Using your hobby knife, or just your fingernail, lift one corner of the label and peel it off.
lines.text_raw: Using your hobby knife, or just your fingernail, lift one corner of the label and peel it off.

lines.text: Give the etched design one final cleaning with rubbing alcohol and a paper towel to remove any leftover adhesive.
lines.text_raw: Give the etched design one final cleaning with rubbing alcohol and a paper towel to remove any leftover adhesive.

guide.summary: Use the label as a built-in resist!
guide.title: Label-Etch a Glass Bottle
